content: The "Safe Academic Facilities and Environments for Tribal Youth Act" or the "SAFETY Act" defines terms like Department, Indian, Indian tribe, and Secretary. It also establishes the Tribal School Construction Demonstration Program. The "SAFETY Act" defines terms like construction of replacement tribal school, demonstration program, eligible Indian tribe, and tribal school. The "Tribal School Construction Demonstration Program" provides grants to eligible Indian tribes for constructing replacement tribal schools, aiming to offer fair opportunities for additional tribes to build new schools. The Tribal School Construction Demonstration Program offers grants to eligible Indian tribes to construct replacement tribal schools, prioritizing tribes on the Department's list for school construction. The Tribal School Construction Demonstration Program offers grants to eligible Indian tribes for constructing replacement tribal schools. Grant applications must include a proposal for construction and be in the form determined by the Secretary. Recipients must enter into an agreement specifying construction costs, a tribal contribution of at least 25%, and other terms set by the Secretary. The Tribal School Construction Demonstration Program offers grants to eligible Indian tribes for constructing replacement tribal schools. Grants received under this program are in addition to other funds received by the tribe and do not affect their eligibility or amount of funding received under other laws. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress at the end of the program to assess its effectiveness. SEC. 4. Funding for Tribal Colleges Construction. Section 113 of the Tribally Controlled Colleges and Universities Assistance Act of 1978 is amended to address the construction of new facilities. The section defines construction for Tribal Colleges or Universities and outlines the grant process for construction projects. Eligible applicants must submit an application to the Secretary for grants. Eligible activities for a grant under this section include building new facilities like classrooms, administrative offices, libraries, health centers, day care centers, technology centers, and other education-related facilities. It also covers renovating or expanding existing facilities and providing equipment such as laboratory equipment, computer infrastructure, and library books. The grant under this section covers property acquisition, including library books and furniture. Recipients are not required to provide matching funds for federal amounts received. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021. SEC. 545 of the Housing Act of 1949 provides housing assistance for educators in schools with Indian students. The term 'covered educator' refers to a full-time teacher, principal, administrator, or licensed professional educator in specific types of schools, including those operated by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, tribally controlled schools, and public schools with at least 25% Indian students. The term 'eligible applicant' in the grant program refers to Indian tribes, Indian organizations, or tribally designated housing entities. The Secretary may award grants to construct, renovate, and repair housing for covered educators in rural areas. Eligible applicants must submit an application to the Secretary. Recipients are not required to provide a non-Federal share. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2017 and beyond. SEC. 6. BIE AND OMB PLAN. The Bureau of Indian Education and the Office of Management and Budget will develop a 10-year plan to improve all Bureau of Indian Education school facilities to good condition, in compliance with tribal requirements. This includes elementary or secondary day or boarding schools, schools under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, tribally controlled schools, and dormitories for students. The Bureau of Indian Education and the Office of Management and Budget will develop a 10-year plan to improve all Bureau of Indian Education school facilities. The plan will include proposed budget requests, timelines, and factors like increasing enrollment capacities. Section 1125(a)(5) of the Education Amendments of 1978 will not apply for plan development. After completion, a report will be submitted to specific committees. The Bureau of Indian Education and the Office of Management and Budget will develop a 10-year plan to improve all Bureau of Indian Education school facilities. The plan will be submitted to specific committees including the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives. The Bureau of Indian Education and the Office of Management and Budget will develop a 10-year plan to improve all Bureau of Indian Education school facilities, which will be submitted to specific committees including the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives. Additionally, a GAO report will be required. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress evaluating the distribution of payments, unmet need, and the condition of school facilities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The local educational agencies enrolling eligible students can receive support payments under specific sections of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act for different fiscal years.
